author: marc_cryan

description.text:
I use this on my MakerFarm Prusa i3v 10".  There's probably better ones out there, but I wanted to make my own (I didn't even search).  
I didn't try other PSUs in it, but I left the outside of the mount open in case I decided to use one with a large fan -- haven't tested that though.  I've included AutoDesk 123D files in case modifications are needed.  
Getting closer to prettying up all the wiring now that I have this :D

Print the base 2x
Print the inside 1x
Print the outside 1x Use acetone to chemically weld all the pieces together. The mount is designed so that you can slide the PSU out the back of it, however I'd highly recommend placing the pieces around your PSU when you chemically weld it. Then clamp it all together and give it time to dry. Use a pen to mark your holes where you want to mount it, then drill -- I only drilled 2 holes for mine. I used some M3 bolts to secure it to the frame of my Prusa.

comments.text: Initially, I thought this might be a less desirable power supply holder and I tried some others but wasn't satisfied. I have a 10" i3v, and some of them are specific to the 8". Anyway, I printed it 1% oversize in PLA which gives just a little extra clearance. I assembled the pieces with Gorilla super glue on the bench using clamps. Because it was slightly oversized, the power supply slides in and out easily. I mounted it on the opposite side to the RAMPS board (opposite the original designer), and with the output cables exiting at the back. This allowed me to just slide the power supply in from the back and not even have to disconnect it from the electronics since I had been using it as a loose bench supply for the past year and it was already hooked up. This orientation and side of the machine prevents a big ball up of cables that might tangle in the x-carriage, and reduces the chances of RF interference with the unshielded RAMPS board. I used a right angle AC power cord to plug into the supply, because there is limited clearance between the power supply and the vertical frame when mounted this way and a straight AC cord would not work. I also used small zip-ties to secure the power supply to the front of the holder going through air holes in the supply and around the upper part of the holder at the front. I mounted it with 5 3mm bolts and nylocks.

title: Look Ma, no hands!! Hands-free Refuse Chute operation (ver 1.0)

description.text: Many modern high-rise dwellings have built-in refuse/ rubbish chutes. If you pull the handle to open the chute with soiled hands, you usually wind up attracting cockroaches. The ick/ hygiene factor also means you should wash your hands properly after using the chute. Presenting: A hands-free solution, where a paddle allows you to operate the chute door with your foot. The printed parts are linked up with electrical wire trunking, minimising prints and leveraging on the strength and flex of the wire trunking. Video: http://youtu.be/Nf_lbvUD9_Y

@@@ BOM: 9 x 1/2 inch screws (+2 optional for extra fastening of paddle)
2 x small screws (see note in Step 9)
1 x 1-1/2 inch bolt and nut
4 x M3 6mm screws (tighten up to 6mm if using longer ones, see Step 4)
1 x 608 bearing
Metal drill bit
1 x length of 1/2 inch (wide) electrical wire trunking (trapezoid shaped)
Print 1 x each STL, 2 x “Chute Handle Clippers”, 2 x “Paddle Door Brace”
*** “Chute Handle Clippers” may need to be modified to fit your chute door handle. @@@ ASSEMBLY:

  • Place “Chute Door Pivot Base” on the side and edge of chute body - where the chute door pivots (but avoid the door of course!).

  • Mark and drill the two holes through the side of the aluminium chute body. Use a drill bit smaller than the screws to allow a tight fit.

  • Add 608 bearing.

  • Add “Chute Door Pivot Cap” and secure with the M3 screws. The top unit should roll freely on the base secured to the chute body.

  • Switch focus to the chute handle: Attach 2 x “Chute Handle Clippers” to chute handle, link them with the electrical wire trunking.

  • Add “Chute Door Axes Link” to the assembly.

  • Link “Chute Door Axes Link” to “Chute Door Pivot Cap” - allow a few inches of excess trunking.

  • Attach “Paddle Base Brace” with long bolt.

  • Attach other “Paddle Base Brace” to the desired angle (with chute door closed). Add bolt and tighten.
    Note: For my prototype set up I drilled two pilot hole (on the bit of excess “ledge” on either face, to add small screws for further locking. Alternatively you can glue the two braces together. I may add a modified bottom brace with “headers” at set angles to avoid this extra step. Leave me a comment or message.

  • Link another length of trunking (to desired length) to BOTH connectors of “Paddle Left”.

  • Attach “Paddle Right” with last 2 screws.

author: Simonwlchan

description.text: Trabalho realizado em SketchUp por formando Diogo Azenha
I was having crosstalk on some wiring.  Spent a few minutes drawing up a versatile wire twister for a variety of wiring arrangements.  It works well enough :)

The wires to be twisted go through the flat bottom first, as the openings are designed to angle in to bring the wires close together where they twist.  
It could probably use some refinement or a nice jig to eliminate the other end from twisting so after some turns the other side needs to be untangled a bit.  This does make it fairly easy to somewhat control the twist and all though.

title: DJI Phantom 2 Carbon Fiber Skid Version 2 Updated 09/02/2017

description.text:
UPDATED 09/02/2017: Strut mount gussets beefed up. See m1-15deg-comp-mnt-v3.stl
see new .stl file! I updated this design to be stronger: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:520060 See that version for compass mount details. You can increase camera protection by clamping or lashing 2mm (.078) carbon fiber tube across the back two legs and across the left and right two legs. I will post more photos and the clamps later. Those two blue things holding the antennas are sections of a drinking straw which is slit the entire length and can be removed and replaced with ease. Works great, easier than tape, and looks better. While I now wrap the compass cable around the leg, it too could get a straw as a protection cover. There are two compass mounts. One uses the stock leg clamp and screws and the other uses just the stock screws (as seen in the photo here). Use whichever you like. In both cases, the flat side faces inboard and is parallel to the front to rear axis of the Phantom. They both must be mounted with the hole closest the the flat side toward the top of the Phantom. In the gallery pictures, the screw mount version is displayed with the bottom hole showing and the top hole is on the far side . You should fit check before gluing with CA glue. If they are upside down you will not be able to align the compass with the front to rear centerline. See the old version for more information.

description.text:
This OpenScad module allows you to generate models for arbitrary Burr puzzle pieces. The bit pattern used for configuration is identical with the one on the following site: http://www.research.ibm.com/BurrPuzzles/index.html You can use the Burr calculator on this site to calculate and print your own puzzles. Additionally, the file contains the burrx() module which allows the corner blocks on the lower level to be set. It basically extends the pattern to 4*L bits. Public domain, because sharing is caring.
Feel free to flattr this if you like the infinite possibilities.

burr (size, length, pattern, tolerance); o size: The size of a single cube. The tile will be (length + 2) * size units wide o length: The length of the pattern. One cube will be added to each side on the top half, two on the bottom half to constitute a block. o pattern: A vector of ones and zeroes that determine whether an individual block is existing or not. o tolerance: Each face of the block will be intruded by the tolerance value in all dimensions. Pattern: A block of size L will require 2 * L + 2 * (L-2) bits. The first bit is on the upper layer, towards the origin. The first L bits are the lower row on the upper layer. The second L bits are the upper row on the upper layer. The third L-2 bits are the lower row on the lower layer. The final L-2 bits are the upper row on the lower layer. Or just play with the bits to get a feeling. The STL file is an example level 6 burr puzzle, which you can also find at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7446

description.text:
With this spool holder you can fix most filament spool sizes, avalailable on the market. Its just compatible with the original M6 threaded rod. For installation you need:

  • 3x hexagon nut M6
    • the .stl-part "fixer" helps you for quick mount of the loose spool holder. yes we know that there are several solutions that way. Our reasons for this creation were some style facts and some technical aspects like bigger range for mounting spool sizes :) PS: You can use this also for M8 rods if you change the 636 bearings to 608. They have the same outer diameter

The impeller don't drive the boats as fast as I wished. So I looked for another way to reach more speed.
An ice sled cause less viscous drag and indeed, it runs so fast that I hardly could control it. Full throttle was only possible for a few seconds. If you give throttle in curves it comes to an about-turn, though it is a perfect emergency break ;-)
Anyway, the indoor ice rink was far to small to make full speed, or I have a lot to train yet...
It is absolutely necessary to use the bumper, otherwise it can damage the transmission gear of the servo. This happened to me as the sled skid uncontrolled against the edging. I recommend to use a bigger servo, they are cheaper anyway.
I know, the winter has already gone, but if you find an ice rink and ask politely, there may be still a way ;-) I want to give thanks to the very friendly and helpfully management of the Eissporthalle Frankfurt/M http://www.eissporthalle-ffm.de/ Here you can find the files for the impeller: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:274054 http://youtu.be/jeEbWfG0DLM

title: Oneup / TwoUp Cool End and Extrduer Fan Duct

description.text:
This is meant to keep the barrel and extruder inlet cooler so the filament doesn't melt to early and cause a jam.  
The duct slides right in on the extruder housing. If the fit is tight enough, it may stay; otherwise, super glue or something will hold it in place. Some light finish work may be required to make it fit nicely.  
I simply glued the 40mm fan on the duct intake.  
The fan runs on an external 12V source so that it remains on.
To avoid the need for supports, print with the duct intake on the bed.

here's a flickr set for this bot
http://www.flickr.com/photos/sixmilliondollardan/sets/72157616240288122/ the zip file is a bunch of solidworks files. SW2006 i think. but i can't remember exactly. i will try to find my parts spreadsheet and toss that up as well. Spring 2008.
I designed and built a simple torso for a Go playing(manipulation driven, not strategy) robot for Prof Rod Brooks at MIT CSAIL. Postdoc Eduardo Torres-Jara works on the motor drivers, control, and hand design. Josh Kargas did some of the electronics mounting and routing. Robot has 6 Series Elastic Actuator degrees of freedom. But waist is locked out and shoulder joints have the spring shorted out. DOFS:
waist yaw
shoulder x 2
elbow x 2
wrist vertical axis x 1
wrist rotation axis x 1
neck pitch x 1
head tilt x 1
head pan x 1 yes analog sensors. potentiometers are awesome.

well, it's pretty safe to say this is a little less than complete documentation and would take a bit to recreate but i thought i would through it up in case anyone wanted to look at it. i will try to answer questions about it if anyone is interested.

comments.text: Impressive indeed. Could have been a holywood mockup of a fancy robot, but this one is for actual research. Does it play go well? Before it plays at all you need Computer vision and control of motoric functions, that's a big challenge already. What's the state of this project?

title: Heated Build Platform Levelling Corner Supports
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: My old MBI HBP died an ignoble death, groaning and grunting before letting out the magic blue smoke. And as we all know, once you let out the magic blue smoke, you're cooked (literally... and then quite un-literally, unfortunately) So I made my own HBP - but the insulation was uneven and resulted in a horribly crooked build platform with a nasty tendency to give more on one side than the other. Very much inspired by: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3453 but to solve a slightly different issue - my HBP isn't a uniform thickness and doesn't have drilled holes in it! An upcoming remix will include my cable clip in one of the corners.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

Cupcake CNC

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

15

• Print the corner clips
  • Use an M3 bolt, place nut in wider part of corner clip and screw M3 bolt through from the bottom
  • Tighten M3 bolt to secure captive nut in cutout - you may need to use pliers to force it in the rest of the way once tightened (the plastic will start bending out of the way of the nut)
  • Put a drop of superglue on the nut to hold it in place
  • Attach two corners to wooden build plate, slide HBP into the tops, tighten screws lightly
  • Attach last two corners and adjust all screws to be tight and have a level top
    • Some of your screws may not go in all the way - this is by design! The corner clamp gets its vertical tension by clamping around the wooden plate and using the screw and captive nut to apply force to the top plate. The screw head does not need to be tight or flush for this to occur. It's horizontal stability is achieved by the screw through the top and bottom holes as well as the wooden build plate holes. The only way these could work any better would be if they had a spring in there somewhere - but then you're talking about even more height sacrificed from build area...

As Marlin integrates a Filament Runout sensor control, I made it with a cheap Slot Type Optical Coupling Module 3.3V-5V LM393. You can buy it for 1,5€ aprox. in Ebay.
It's for 3mm filament.
Arm.STL is for install it in the free motor screw hole of a typical Greg's Extruder.
Not tested yet with Marlin. I tested it with an Arduino UNO and works like Marlin needs (LOW when filament out).

BOM:
3 Printed parts (0.2 layer)
1 M3 8mm. screw
2 M3 10mm. screws
1 M3 25mm. screw
2 M3 nuts
2 M3 Nylon lock nuts
1 M3 screw to conect to your Extruder motor Conect it to your RAMPS board as you can see in diagram. Marlin uses pin D4 on SERVOS group (RAMPS board) for input. Then uncomment this line in your Configuration.h file:
//#define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR
And upload yor fimware NOTE:
Marlin generates an M600 Gcode when filament is out. You must have this option enabled in 'Configuration_adv.h, uncommenting:
// #define FILAMENT_CHANGE_FEATURE

author: design1948

title: Nakamichi CM-300 Microphone battery adapter insert

description.text:
The Nakamichi CM-300 microphones are an old condenser microphone that works extremely well with acoustic instruments and are pretty inexpensive. But they use a 9V battery which is hard to find and doesn't last very long. I found a pair of batteries - a 3v and a 6v that stacked up fit in the microphone body - except they're skinnier and flop around a bit. This adapter keeps the batteries in the middle of the body. The batteries are a CR2 (readily available) and an A544 (hard to find in stores) Both available from www.cheap-batteries.com much cheaper than I've found them retail.
NOTE! These microphones will work at up to 14 volts, and so stacking 2 of the A544's (equaling 12V) will work even better than the 6V+3V.
If you are interested, I will send you several for a few dollars to cover S/H Go to http://www.untiedmusic.com/3d.
There's also a YouTube video on this at: https://youtu.be/RIbleGGWFsI

author: salvodipa

title: Optical Density Sensor aka Kafi-Schnapps Detektor

description.text: This standalone sensor allows to measure the optical density (OD) aka turbidity through a standardized cuvette. 1-Channel for different wavelengths use multiple sensors with different 5mm LEDs. The design fits nicely a TIL-99 phototransistor. see more on: http://hackteria.org/?p=2194

The layers were made using 3mm MDF and laser cut. The settings for rastering need to be optimized to have the right thickness to perfectly fit the LED in between. Same for the depth of the pin-header row. The sensor can be read using an arduino or a BabyMidiGnusbuino. Various tests have been run on the BabyMidiGnusbuino (a 2$ variant arduino compatible a85 platform), using pure data and MIDI to talk to the sensor. Especially Kafi-Schnapps is very useful for calibration and getting the detection limits of the sensor.
http://wiki.sgmk-ssam.ch/index.php/Babygnusbuino see details on: http://hackteria.org/wiki/index.php/DIY_spectrophotometer

This is a replacement part for what for the lack of a better name, I will call a mop holder roller.  
The old one split in two and we have several of these things in our pantry and rather than buying something new and drilling new holes, I thought I would test my skill on Sketchup.  
I took my handy digital caliper, priceless when replicating parts, and took measurements off the broken one.  I exported from Sketchup and ran the STL through Netfabb studio to make sure it was clean.  
Sorry about the photo quality, these are cropped from iPad photos.

I printed it in ABS, no raft, one extra shell in Makerware, 10% infill.  The open end is up.  
Part works, see the pics.  I snapped it on, turned it a few times to loosen it up and hung something as a test.

title: Makergear M2 Filament Drive with Shrouds V3B Hotend

description.text:
Working great on my M2 so far :)
Dial indicator mount added- drawn for the harbor freight dial indicator. Please note that the filament path can print tight on these, causing dragging. You will need to manually run some filament through the filament drive until it is smooth. I had binding initially, but that should cure it. This set is designed to ideally be used with slipshine's m2 printer spool holder, thing 37210 but should work with the factory tube.
It is also designed to be used with the V3b Hotend as well as two 40mm fans. This set will NOT fit the 50mm bed fan. I have made small changes to the factory M2 Filament drive including:
Notch for gear inspection and cleaning
Dovetails for shroud mounting
Adjusted for easier inserting of V3b hotend
Smoother filament opening for less initial binding
Smoother filament path
Slightly enlarged top filament hole for easier color swap
Slightly enlarged nut traps The shrouds are designed to be quick on/off and to help cool the barrel of the hotend without excessive air on the melt zone (hopefully requiring less retraction). Thanks for Mrcleanr6 and his nice dovetailed-drive which inspired mine. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:344950 I hope to soon incorporate a similar path as the drive designed by
cas00176 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:717414
For work with flexible filament.

Printed well on my m2 using ABS for the filament drive and PLA for the rest of the parts.  
I printed at a 0.3 layer, 25% infill and 3 layers for top, bottom, and outlines.   
The bed shroud can use some support but I printed one without it The filament drive also needs support.  I suggest adding your own support manually to the filament drive to avoid the support fusing with the exterior walls.

title: Glue Stick Holder for M3D Micro

description.text:
Use a glue stick to keep your prints  from lifting? Have problems with misplacing your glue stick? Why not make a glue stick holder that mounts to your Micro!   
My first time designing anything for my printer so I decided to just keep it simple!
Printed on low quality and low fill and took 4 hrs to print.

comments.text: I have found that some of my prints curl and then warp, lastly sometimes are knocked off of the bed.  Does a glue stick really make a difference? If so, any useful links or videos for good instruction?
comments.author: blisk

comments.text: With over 100 hours of successful prints on my micro while using my Elmer's glue stick I can definitely say the glue stick is crucial to guarantee your prints do not warp or lift off the print bed. What I do is use blue painters tape and place that directly on top of the print bed, smooth it down with a plastic putty knife to get the bubbles out, then apply the glue stick to the area you are going to be printing and you shouldn't have issues.

description.text:
This is a single model from a much larger project I've been working on for a couple of years, it is a "design study" of the "Jupiter 2" from the TV show "Lost in Space", some of you may recognize the "Robot", the overall design of the entire ship is over 500 parts, I'm currently printing a model of just the support frame of the ship over 80 parts, it is turning out to be over 2 1/2 feet in diameter, I have the first of three decks printed and assembled, tonight I will complete the second deck and hope to have the final model printed and assembled by next week(this model was completed and sold to a collector), I may upload images but I'm don't think I can upload so many parts so if someone is interested they will have to contact me and we can discuss it.
Here is a link to the new project:
http://pp3dp.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=14&t=4845&sid=37636b2037ee0a7689503bbfa0bed9b7
An old page http://home.comcast.net/~elainepetitclerc/new_page_1.htm

I've not yet printed him so I have no idea what some of the small details will look like, he is one model, perhaps later I will try to cut him up into more manageable parts.
In the UP! file he is at a scale of 2:1 to what I will print him for the 2 1/2 foot diameter model.

remixed_from.author: oscahie
remixed_from.title: E3D v6 hot-end mod for Da Vinci 1.0

description.text: This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:608560 for the Da Vinci 1. My instructions still apply but I suggest you use this thing to download from. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1344230 I changed the drill template because the holes are in different locations for the Duo. I made the "Head A" a little taller so the filament is aligned with the drive gear. This makes it easier to load the filament. I added some pockets for the Screws on "Head B" so the 30 mm screws will work. Read the Instructions for more details.

For more information please read my full instructions here http://voltivo.com/forum/davinci-hwmods/353-replace-the-extruder-hot-end#2749 In order to do this same mod you will need the following.
Dremel (or a drill and something else to cut hard plastic away with)
4x screws Diameter M3 (3mm) Pitch .50 (that's how far apart the threads are.) and 30mm long.
a few zip ties
2x E3D v6 Extruders. (Lite version works as well)
2x 3mm washers Print two sets of the clamps. One set for each extruder. The drill template is used to line up where to drill your holes. You will need to line up the template on one side then the other so you are drilling holes for the first extruder then the second. I did not drill out the large hols around the stepper motor shaft. Instead I lightly scored that large circle with my dremel as you can see in the pictures. Use the washers between the plastic clamps and the Metal arms. IF YOU DO NOT DO THIS THEN the filament may appear to jam. The drive gear will spin and the filament will not move. This is because the plastic clamps can put pressure on the idler arm and cause it to not pinch the filament as tight. Rather than cut and splice wires for the heaters I just reused my old heaters from the original Da Vinci hot ends. They work just fine. I will keep the new ones around as spare parts. You cannot do the same thing with the original thermal couple though. The stock one is too large to fit into the E3D Hot end block. However, the 2pin wire connectors that come with the E3D hot ends for the thermal couples can be used on the circuit board that comes with the Da Vinci 2. All you have to do is slide the white plastic connector off the pins to make room for the new black connector. As shown in the pictures. I used zip ties to attach the circuit board to the top where it will be out of the way. I have this mod working. The hard part was making the two Hot Ends level. I was able to leave the screws loose then move the hot ends into place until they were level. Then I tightened the Screws. I also ordered two 30mm 5v fans to replace the 12v ones that came with the E3Ds. In the meantime I will have to wire the fans up to some other 12 volt power source. I also cut out some additional vents on the sides where the fans are so they can breath a little easier. I want the fans to pull the hot air out to the sides rather than push all the hot air into the middle. I also suggest this Mod to help cool the plastic as it prints. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:553792

comments.text: Yo! Thanks for making the remix of this for the Da Vinci 2. I had an issue on my printer where I'm guessing I just didn't drill the holes "quite" in the right spot, so one of the heads was a bit higher than the other. To combat this, I modified your remix to be a slot like screw hole instead of just a normal one. It works great. I just have to make sure the bed is super level to the gantry, then with the screws only partially in to where the print can slide up and down, I just raised the bed with some paper between the bed and heads. This forced them into alignment. :D Then I just tightened the screws and TADA!!!! Fully working! (It was like 2mm difference in height, now they don't scrape across the top of each other. Was even printing with black and white filaments and there was no problems with streaking or anything)

comments.text: One more question, do I need to upgrade printer's firmware to make hothead work?
comments.author: mordiev

comments.text: Ah.  Good question.  In short I will say yes. You need to flash the firmware in order for it to work.  The long answer is that you MIGHT be able to get around that.  The problem that you will run into is the filament jam sensors on the circuit board.  There is a sensor that watches to see if the Idler wheel is spinning.  That is why it has black and white sections painted on it.  With this mod that sensor is moved so it cannot see the idler wheel.  So the sensor will assume the filament has jammed and that is why it can't see the wheel spin.  You could try to find a way to mount that circuit so it can still see the spinning wheel.  Your choice.
comments.author: leadpan

comments.text:
Hi.

comments.author: deuse

comments.text: I Tried to get that figured out at first.  I gave up.  There are two major problems with this idea of only changing out one of the hot ends.  #1 it will be hard to physically attach them both and make them work.  E3D is about 2 cm longer so you would have to design some sort of custom tool head that can hold each hot end at a different height.  That would involve some 3D modeling and a lot of trial and error. #2 you will have to figure out how to control the temperature better.  The thermistor that comes with the E3D is smaller and has a different Resistance value. So you can't have a mix of each type.  You would need to drill out the hole on the E3D to fit the stock thermistor or you would have to buy a second E3D thermistor.   Keep in mind there are a LOT of cheap knock off out there that don't work well.

author: Maxxi

description.text:
This includes files that are designed to assist with printing using a large spool on the MakerBot Replicator 2.
The Spool Spacer will keep the spool away from any items that may catch it on the back fo the printer. Stack them to gain additional clearance or check out the SCAD file.
The Tube Spacer works great for both moving the tube closer to the middle of a large spool as well as many other sizes. The second major use for this is to make it easier to use your older mangled tubes that just don't stay clipped in properly anymore.
As some people have issues with their spool unwinding we have also included a friction based tensioner that can be added to the tube spacer and fastened with a M3 bolt.

This should be fairly easy to print. We used 3 shells and 20% fill on these parts but they aren't going to be picky.
orient the tube holder so the flat surface is down. It may have a few loose strings inside the tube chamber but the overhang is reasonable enough to print without any significant issues. To use the Tensioner flap a M3 bolt is required.
